Second Lieutenant R.F. AKERMAN
11th Battalion London Regiment (Finsbury Rifles)
Died 3rd October 1915
Ralph Portland Akerman was born in 1888 to Ada nee BAKER and Portland Board AKERMAN, a solicitor in London.

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
An online genealogy shows the following:

PORTLAND BOARD AKERMAN was born on 12 December 1861 in Bridgwater, Somerset.  He was named after Portland cement!  (His grandfather, John Board, cement entrepreneur, had died a year previously).  He grew up in Castle House, Queen Street.  In 1886, he married ADA BAKER, daughter of Henry and Elizabeth Baker, also of Bridgwater.  She was born in 1865.  They lived at various addresses in London and he worked as a solicitor.  He wrote a handbook to the local government act, 1894.  He also branched into writing fiction with ‘Triscombe Stone: A Romance of the Quantock Hills’ (1897).  He died on 28 December 1931 at 12a Challoner Mansions, Challoner Street, West Kensington, London. 

Portland Board Akerman and Ada Baker had the following children: 

        i.            RALPH PORTLAND AKERMAN was born in 1888 in Brixton, London.  He grew up at various addresses in London and was educated at St Olave’s Grammar School, Orpington.  He served in WW1 as a 2nd Lieutenant in the 11th Battalion (Finsbury Rifles); he died from wounds on 03 October 1915 and is buried at Netley Military Cemetery, near Southampton.

      ii.            JACK PHILLIPS AKERMAN was born on 16 December 1891 in Brixton, London.  He grew up at various addresses in London and, prior to 1914, was in Argentina.  It is likely that he was working there alongside his cousin Edward.  On return, like his cousin, he served in France as a Lieutenant in Prince Albert’s (Somerset Light Infantry) during WW1 and was awarded the Military Cross.  Towards the end of the war, he helped to found the tank corps.  In 1926, he joined the Indian Army.  In 1927, he married HOPE KATHLEEN LAND in Calcutta, India.  She was born in 1895 and was the daughter of Harold Cunningham Land and Florence Cuell of Bickley, Kent.  Jack retired from the Indian Army in 1946 as Colonel and was awarded an OBE.  He died in 1978 in Weston-Super-Mare, Somerset.
